Name: What is Computer Networking?
Description: Computer networking involves connecting two or more computing devices (like PCs, smartphones, servers, printers) to communicate and share resources. These networks help businesses, educational institutions, and homes to share:
Content: Files and media
Internet access
Hardware (e.g., printers, scanners)
Applications and software services
Note: A network can be as simple as two connected computers or as vast as the internet, which connects millions of devices globally.

Name: Types of Networks
Discription: Here are more use-case examples and comparisons:

Subheadings.Name: LAN (Local Area Network)
Content: Used in homes, offices, schools
Example: Your home Wi-Fi with a few connected devices

Subheadings.Name: WAN (Wide Area Network)
Content: Covers large geographical areas
Example: The internet connecting multiple cities and countries

Subheadings.Name: MAN (Metropolitan Area Network)
Content: Connects users in a city or town
Often maintained by ISPs or government entities

Subheadings.Name: PAN (Personal Area Network)
Content: Very limited range, typically 10 meters
Example: Connecting your mobile phone to wireless earphones or smartwatch

Subheadings.Name: Router
Content: Manages traffic between your network and the internet
Can assign IP addresses using DHCP
May offer port forwarding, firewall settings, and QoS (Quality of Service)

Subheadings.Name: Switch
Content: Smarter than a hub; knows where to send data
Used in enterprise networks to connect many computers

Subheadings.Name: Modem
Content: Stands for modulator-demodulator
Converts signals between digital (used by your devices) and analog (used by phone lines)

Subheadings.Name: Firewall
Content: Can be hardware (external box) or software (like Windows Defender Firewall)
Blocks unauthorized access and filters malicious traffic

Subheadings.Name: Wired Pros:
Content: Stable connection
Faster data transmission
More secure (harder to intercept)

Subheadings.Name: Wired Cons:
Content: Cables can clutter
Less mobility

Subheadings.Name: Wireless Pros:
Content: Convenient for mobile devices
Easy to expand the network

Subheadings.Name: Wireless Cons:
Content: Susceptible to interference
Slower and less secure unless encrypted

Subheadings.Name: IP Address
Content: A unique string (like 192.168.0.1) that identifies a device on a network.

Subheadings.Name: Private vs Public IP
Content: Private: Used within local networks; not routed on the internet
Public: Assigned by ISP for global access

Subheadings.Name: Static vs Dynamic IP
Content: Static: Manually set; doesn't change
Dynamic: Assigned by DHCP; can change over time

Name: DNS (Domain Name System)
Description: DNS acts like a Phonebook for the internet:
Content: Converts human-friendly domain names (like facebook.com) into IP addresses (157.240.20.35)
Without DNS, we’d have to remember numerical IPs instead of names
DNS servers can be provided by your ISP or custom ones (e.g., Google DNS: 8.8.8.8)

Name: Protocols
Description: Protocols are rules that define how data is transferred.

Subheadings.Name: Common Protocols
Content: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) – Ensures reliable and ordered data delivery
IP (Internet Protocol) – Routes data packets to their destination
HTTP/HTTPS – Used for web browsing (HTTPS is secure)
FTP – Used for transferring files
SMTP/IMAP/POP3 – Used for sending and receiving emails
DHCP – Assigns IP addresses automatically
DNS – Resolves domain names to IP addresses
ICMP – Used in diagnostic tools like ping

Name: OSI Model
Description: A conceptual framework for how data travels:
Content: Physical – Hardware (cables, ports).
Data Link – MAC addressing, switching.
Network – IP addressing, routing.
Transport – Reliable data transfer (TCP).
Session – Manages sessions.
Presentation – Data translation, encryption.
Application – Interfaces with user applications (e.g., browsers).

Name: Network Security Basics
Content: WPA2/WPA3: – Wi-Fi encryption standards. Use WPA3 if available.
MAC Address Filtering: – Only allows specific devices to connect
VPN (Virtual Private Network): – Encrypts your internet traffic and hides your IP
Two-Factor Authentication (2FA): – Adds an extra layer of login security
Note: Avoid using public WI-FI without VPNs, as they're common places for hackers to snoop.

Subheadings.Name: Basic Commands
Content: ping <host> – Checks if a host is reachable
tracert <host> – Shows the path packets take to a host
ipconfig (Windows) / ifconfig (Linux/macOS) – Shows IP configuration
netstat – Displays network connections and ports in use
nslookup – Checks DNS resolution

Subheadings.Name: Advanced Tools
Content: Wireshark – Packet sniffer for analyzing network traffic
Nmap – Network scanner for discovering hosts and services
